tn.text: Paul names himself as the writer of this letter to the believers at the church at Ephesus.
Except where noted, all instances of "you" and "your" refers to the Ephesian believers as well as all believers and so are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Paul, an apostle ... to God's holy people in Ephesus
tn.text: Your language may have a particular way of introducing the author of a letter and its intended audience. AT: "I, Paul, an apostle ... write this letter to you, God's holy people Ephesus"

tn.ref: who are faithful in Christ Jesus
tn.text: "In Christ Jesus" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a common greeting and blessing that Paul often uses in his letters.
Paul opens his letter by talking about the believers' position and their safety before God.
In this book, unless otherwise stated, the words "us" and "we" refer to Paul, the believers in Ephesus, as well as all believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: May the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ be praised
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "Let us praise the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"for God has blessed us"
"every blessing coming from the Spirit of God"
"in the supernatural world." The word "heavenly" refers to the place where God is.

"In Christ" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.
Paul uses two similar words to emphasize moral goodness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The words "his," "He," and "he" refer to God.

tn.ref: God chose us beforehand for adoption
tn.text: The word "us" refers to Paul, the Ephesian church, and all believers in Christ. AT: "God planned long ago to adopt us" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
Here "adoption" refers to being placed in God's family.
God brought believers into his family by the work of Jesus Christ.
"the One he loves, Jesus Christ" or "his Son, whom he loves"
Paul speaks of God's grace as if it were material wealth. AT: "greatness of God's grace" or "abundance of God's grace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He lavished this grace upon us
tn.text: "He gave us this great amount of grace" or  "He was extremely kind to us"
Possible meanings are 1) "because he has all wisdom and understanding" 2) "so that we might have great wisdom and understanding"
Possible meanings are 1) "because he wanted to make it known to us" or 2) "which was what he wanted."

tn.ref: and which he demonstrated in Christ
tn.text: "and he demonstrated this purpose in Christ"
"by means of Christ"

tn.ref: with a view to a plan
tn.text: A new sentence can be started here. AT: "He did this with a view to a plan" or "He did this, thinking about a plan"
"for when the time is right" or "for the time that he has appointed"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God chose us to be heirs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"God chose us earlier"

tn.ref: so that we might be the first
tn.text: Here the word "we" refers to the Jewish believers who first heard the good news, not the believers at Ephesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: so we would be for the praise of his glory
tn.text: "so that we would live to praise him for his glory"

tn.ref: were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit
tn.text: Wax was placed on a letter and stamped with a symbol representing the person who wrote the letter. Paul uses this custom as a picture to show how God has used the Holy Spirit to assure us that we belong to him. AT: "God has sealed you with the Holy Spirit that he promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Receiving what God has promised is spoken of as though one inherits property or wealth from a family member. AT: "the guarantee that we will receive what God has promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul prays for the Ephesian believers and praises God for the power that believers have through Christ.

tn.ref: I have not stopped thanking God
tn.text: Paul uses "not stopped" to emphasize that he continues to thank God. AT: "I continue to thank God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: a spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of him
tn.text: "spiritual wisdom to understand his revelation"

tn.ref: that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened
tn.text: The phrase "eyes of your heart" expresses one's ability to gain understanding. AT: "that you may gain understanding and be enlightened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: that the eyes of your heart may be enlightened
tn.text: This may be stated in the active tense. AT: that God may enlighten your heart" or "that God may enlighten your understanding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"made to see"
Receiving what God has promised believers, is spoken of as if one were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in the active tense. AT: "all those whom he has set apart for himself" or "all those who belong completely to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the immeasurable greatness of his power
tn.text: God's power is far beyond all other power.
"for our benefit" or "in relation to us"

tn.ref: the working of his great strength
tn.text: "his great power that is at work for us"

tn.ref: raised him from the dead ones
tn.text: "raised him from death" or "made him alive again"

tn.ref: seated him at his right hand
tn.text: "seated Christ at God's right hand" or "seated Christ in the place of honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"in the supernatural world." The word "heavenly" refers to the place where God is. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:eph:01:03|1:3]].

tn.ref: far above all rule and authority and power and dominion
tn.text: These are different terms for the ranks of supernatural beings, both angelic and demonic. AT: "far above all types of supernatural beings"
This can be stated in active form. AT: Possible meanings are 1) "every name that man gives" or 2) "every name that God gives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Possible meanings are 1) title or 2) position of authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"at this time"
"in the future"
"God placed" or "God has put" (UDB)
Here "feet" represents Christ's lordship, authority, and power. AT: "all things under Christ's power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: has made him the head ... his body
tn.text: Just as with a human body, the head rules all things pertaining to its body, so Christ is the head of the church body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the head over all things in the church
tn.text: Here "head" refers to the leader or the one who is in charge. AT: "ruler over all things in the church" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The church is often referred to as the body of Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the fullness of him who fills all things in all ways
tn.text: "Christ fills the church with his life and power just as he gives life to all things"
